text:
Moist, delicious and YUMMY!  I've made without altering and it is delicious but ofcourse I always take it to another level which is even YUMMIER!  I used 3 cups of zucchini instead of 2, 2 cups white sugar and 1/4 cup brown sugar instead of all white sugar and added a sprinkle of nutmeg.  I also make a  crumb topping( 2/3 cup flour, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 cup chopped walnuts and 1 stick softened butter-mix altogether with hand) and sprinkle all over the top of the loaves before baking.  Now- that is one heck of a good loaf of blueberry zucchini bread!  Will not leave my recipe box!

text:
This was wonderful!  I did make changes:  half white/half whole wheat flour, used 1/2 cup canola oil and 1/2 cup applesauce, and less sugar.  I also made a crumb topping with equal parts flour, sugar and oatmeal mixed with cinnamon and enough smart balance spread to make it crumbly.  This was to die for, really, I couldn't stay away!  I will make this again and again!  Thanks for sharing the recipe!

this recipie is the best zucchini bread recipie i have ever had. 2 things that i do to kind of kick it up a notch is i use half applesause and half oil, and i mix together 1 teaspoon cinnamon, 1 teaspoon brown sugar, 1 teaspoon white sugar and 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg and i sprinkle it in the loaf pans prior to pouring in the batter.

text:
Wonderful recipe and an ingenous way to use up the mountains of zucchini that come out of summer gardens! Increased the zucchini to 2.5 cups and ensured that I squeezed the water out of the zucchini by lightly salting it and letting it "weep" for 20 minutes or so.  I changed the flour ingredient to: 1/2 white flour and 1/2 whole wheat flour and used 1/2 cup of applesauce and 1/2 cup oil vs 1 cup of oil for a healthier recipe.  On a side note;  to prevent your blueberries from sinking to the bottom of the pan, coat them in flour before adding.  This will help them bind to the batter.  Enjoy!

text:
I made this twice.  The first time it was terrible!  I made a half recipe for a standard loaf but there wasn’t enough batter to fill the pan adequately, so I had to sub  with a smaller pan that just didn’t seem right to me.  As it baked it rose unevenly,  with a square, level top, not the nicely rounded top it should have.  After repeatedly checking it for doneness I finally gave up – I didn’t want to mess with it anymore.  As I turned it out of the pan directly into the garbage can rather than onto a cooling rack,  it somehow finally dawned on me that I forgot to include the zucchini in this Blueberry ZUCCHINI Bread!   So I tried it again.  It was just the right amount of batter for an 8x4” loaf pan.  As it baked it was fragrant and developed a nicely risen, rounded top.  It was moist, with a compact yet tender crumb, chock full of blueberries and pretty specks of zucchini.  It was full of flavor, delightfully sweet with a delicate hint of cinnamon.  It was perfect.  I am not.   Don’t forget the zucchini.

text:
This is a great recipe as is, and also works well with some healty substitutions (1/2 whole wheat flour 1/2 white, 1/2 applesauce for the oil).  I have also made muffins from this recipe, just up the baking powder to 3 tbsp for a more cake-like texture. I also like to sprinkle them with a little raw sugar before baking to add a nice little crunch. Thanks so much for this great recipe!  A family favorite!

text:
Just made these for the first time this morning, but followed some advice from previous reviews.  Substituted half the oil with applesauce, used only 1 1/2 cups sugar and sprinkled a combination of 2T sugar and 2T brown sugar on top.  Baked as muffins for 25 minutes.  This recipe made about 21 muffins.  Next time, I'll use a little less blueberries--maybe 1 1/2 cups.  Great recipe!  Will definitely make again!

text:
This is only the second time I have left a 5 star review.  I made this bread for a work event today.  I have to say it is one of the best.  The zucchini & blueberry combination is to die for.  I normally don't review if I have made changes.  I feel the recipe should be rated as printed.  However this one I did reduce sugar to 1-1/2 cup (personal preference), baked in a bundt pan (took 1 hour @ 350*) and when cool dusted with powdered sugar. Nothing too major.  I will definitely be making again.  The great thing about this recipe (besides it is just great) is you can make as a loaf, muffins, 9 X 13 or bundt pan style.  Don't hesitate to try this one.  You will be glad you did.  Thanks for posting.

text:
Loved this recipe! This recipe made 4 mini loaves and 1 regular size loaf for me. The only thing I did different was add 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar and it turned out GREAT! It was sweet, moist and delicious... and everyone ate it up!  UPDATE: I added a struessel topping before baking and it made it even more delicious! (1/2 cup flour, 1/2 oat meal, 1/2 cup chopped walnuts or pecans, 2 tsp. cinnamon, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 6 tbsp. butter. Mix all together and sprinkle on top of bread batter before baking).

text:
I have made this several times and followed some tips from other chefs, and added my own twists. Here is my favorite version:  Use half white and half whole wheat flour; use ALL unsweetened applesauce instead of the oil; use 3 c zucchini instead of 2 c.  Cut sugar down to 1 3/4 cups and use half white and half brown sugar; add 1 cup of unsweetened shredded coconut to the dry ingredients; and substitute 1 tsp of the vanilla for 1 tsp of coconut extract. Since I prefer muffins to loaves, I also used 5 tsp of baking powder to give it extra rise (you need more baking powder than the original recipe calls for when you use whole wheat flour).

Total calorie count on 12 servings is 5500, so 1 slice would be  460 cal. If you substitute 1/2 oil for 1/2 apple sauce, 1  cup of sugar for splenda, 1.5 cup of flour for 1.5 cup of whole wheat, total calorie count comes to 3500.

text:
100% kid (and mom) approved!  These were fantastic, and the recipe holds up incredibly well to some easy healthy changes.  I used 3/4 cup natural applesauce and 1/4 cup canola oil; used only 1 1/2 cups sugar (which I will further reduce next time to probably only 1 cup); and used 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup whole wheat flour, and 1 cup oat flour (made by grinding oats in my food processor).  I used 2 cups frozen blueberries and didn't waste time rinsing them - some of the muffins were blue in color but that was kind of fun for the kids and still yummy.  Everything else was as specified.  The recipe doubles incredibly well.  I filled muffin tins to the very top and got 30 muffins from this (when I doubled the recipe).

text:
This recipe is not very forgiving. I used a smallish zucchini (which I also drained of a lot of its liquid). It yielded a little more than the 2 cups indicated in the recipe. The batter ended up being the proverbial 10 lbs. of stuff in a 5 lb. bag. It rose like the dickins in the oven and overflowed the pan. So... the 4 mini pans don't begin to cover the room needed for this batter. Try using at least 5 if not 6 mini pans. Also, the recipe indicates a "light" greasing of the pans is needed. I greased them well and yet two of the loaves stuck to the bottom of the pans. I only used 2 C sugar instead of the 2 1/4 C required by the recipe, and it still was overly sweet. Also, even when it's cut the next day, it doesn't cut well; it easily crumbles.

OK, this rocked, although I made a lot of adjustments.  I made it more healthy, and it still was raved about. I halved the oil, and added applesauce. I used half whole wheat flour. I cut the sugar to 2 cups, and then used 1 cup of Brown sugar instead.  I also added 1/4 cup of ground flax seed for the omega fatty acids.  Also, my blueberries were a very ROUNDED 2 cups.  This was so moist and delish. The kids inhaled it!  Yummy delish!

text:
Wow, these were so adorable and delicious. I added the crumb topping suggested by cookiequeen and that takes this fantastic recipe to irresistible and amazing. For Christmas gifts I made these and two other different types of bread from this site and this recipe was hands down the winner. I used frozen blueberries with flour dusted on them so they wouldn't fall to the bottom, half apple sauce and half oil, 3 cups shredded zucchini, 2 cups white sugar and 1/4 cup brown sugar, and a dash of nutmeg. I baked these in mini-loaf pans (8 mini-loaves per pan) and I yielded 16 mini-loaves (2 pans). Baked them for 20 minutes. I've already been asked to make these again.

AWESOME recipe!!  Of course, I made a few changes because I can't stand to follow a recipe without changing it to be my own!  :)  I used spelt flour instead of AP flour to bump the nutrition and fiber.  I used 3 cups of zucchini instead of 2 cups.  I cut the sugar to 2 cups, but will cut it even more next time. Lastly, instead of 1 cup oil, I used 1/2 cup of olive oil and 1/2 cup of greek yogurt. This bread was SO yummy!  I will definitely be making this again!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Awesome! On a whim I decided to try this simply because I had 2 large zucchinis and a ton of fresh blueberries to use up. I ended up with 2 1/2 cups of shredded zucchinis and a little more than one pint of fresh blueberries. Other than that, I followed everything else called for in the recipe. The ingredients is easy to put together and batter mixes up well. I filled two mini-loaf pans plus a little leftover for a total of 21 mini-loaves. They baked up beautifully all in 50 minutes. I could smell the scent of fresh blueberries baking up in the oven and the essence of cinnamon...oh my! I can see the blueberries bubbling up as they bake. This turned out to be a pleasant surprise for me. A nice combination of blueberries and zucchini this truly is! The zucchini bakes right into the loaves and works perfectly with the blueberries.  The bread is soo moist and tender. The berries itself is juicy with its sweet berries bursting in each mouthful! This is the cutest mini-loaf ever with all the purple/blue bluberries oozing all over the bread. And with the green little specks of zucchinis right along with the berries, it makes this so pretty! The lovely hint of cinnamon is also there. With the exception of the extra bluberries I added, this recipe is good as is! I would not change this at all. It is very moist, tender, flavorful and delicious!

I made these and took them to the office and they were a big hit. This was moist and delicious no matter what you add or change in this recipe.  I made 2 large loaves and substituted egg beaters to watch my husbands cholesterol, substituted 1 cup Splenda for the sugar and as as another reader did used 1/2 cup applesauce for some of the oil and 1 cup of whole wheat flour.  To add extra fiber I added 1/4 cup of Fiber One, 2 Tbsp. Wheat Bran, 1/4 cup Raisin Bran & 1/2 cup chopped nuts. I sprinkled the top of each loaf with Raw Sugar so it had a crisp top and very moist inside - My husband loved it and ate 1/2 a loaf in one sitting :-)

text:
I made exactly as recipe stated and it turned out very well and was so good!  I didn't have mini loaf pans, so I used two regular loaf pans.

I'm docking it one star because I believe the recipe uses way too much sugar and would be just as good by taking it down to just 1 1/2 cups or so.  I also think the amount of cinnamon called for was too much.  While I do love cinnamon, when I bit into the bread it was the first thing I smelled and tasted and it was rather dominating.  I think half the amount should work fine.  Plus, I think I may add in more zucchini next time.  Left as-is the recipe should be renamed Cinnamon Blueberry Bread because those are the only two flavors that come through.

text:
Great recipe.  I always try to change recipes to cut out as many simple carbs as I can.  I have a really picky kid, and it's one way I feel I can sneak in healthier choices. Sometimes it works well, and sometimes it is a flop!  With this recipe, it worked really well.  I used 1 cup applesauce (no oil)l, 1 1/4 cup brown sugar (no white sugar) and 2 1/2 cups whole wheat flour (no white flour).  I find the all natural applesauce has enough sweetness that you can cut way back on the sugar.  I also cut out the cinnamon as we don't like cinnamon.  My super picky daughter loves it!  Thanks for sharing!

These are very good.  I followed other reviewer suggestions and used half applesauce in place of part of the oil and cut the sugar (to 3/4 cup for a half recipe) to make a not-too-sweet, healthy breakfast muffin.  I would like to try these again with more sugar as written when I need a sweeter treat.  I also had 50 percent extra zucchini, so I just went ahead and used it all, and it worked out great.  A half recipe yielded a dozen muffins with nice, round tops.  Loved the blueberry, zucchini, vanilla, cinnamon combination...great tasting and healthy too.

Wonderful! 

I did change the recipe to healthify it up :) I cut the sugar in half and used 2 overripe bananas smashed. I also cut the oil in half and used a 1/2 cup of applesauce in its place. I then followed the direction of other people who reviewed it and used half all purpose flour and 1/2 whole wheat flour.

I used two standard sized loaf pans and cooked for about an hour and ten minutes and they came out perfectly!

text:
I just made this today and it turned out really moist & delicious. I wanted to add the crumble topping some reviewers mention, but didn't have the brown sugar on hand. I'm a huge fan of the crumbles, but after making it plain, I don't think it needed it after all.

I used frozen blueberries and they worked perfectly. I didn't thaw them or anything, but just stirred them in frozen. 

I didn't have mini loaf pans either, so I used 2 separate pans. One 9 x 11 glass pan, and a 4 x 9 glass loaf pan. This configuration required a cooking time of 1 hr 10 minutes.

My husband doesn't like blueberries, but I love them. I'll eat the little loaf and take the big pan to work tomorrow. I can't wait to be everyone's favorite! ;)

None
text:
Excellent! To make the recipe more low fat, I used 3/4 cup applesauce and 1/4 cup olive oil. Used 1/2 white flour and 1/2 wheat flour.  I also only used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/2 cup white sugar. Used a crumble topping on top with 3/4 cup sugar, 1/4 cup flour, 1 T. cinnamon and 1/4 cup margarine.  Cooked in 2 loaf pans for 1 hour and 15 minutes. If using frozen blueberries, I used 2 cups and let them thaw while putting the rest of the ingredients together. Will definitely make again and again!

text:
I made this exactly as written...except I did a few modifications to make this healthier.  First I substituted 1/2 cup applesauce for half of the oil, reduced the sugar to just 2cups and used half wheat flour in place of half white flour.  I kept everything else exactly the same.  These were so yummy.  I made a quick little crumb topping using oats, sugar, brown sugar, cinnamon and enough Country Crock Light to make it wet.  These are a big hit in my house and a wonderful way to use up extra zucchini from the garden.  Will use this recipe for years to come!

text:
This was GREAT.  And ridiculously foolproof.  I halved the sugar, and found it plenty sweet; used 2 cups whole wheat flour, 1 cup white, substituted most of the oil for apple sauce, and a bit of yogurt that I was trying to get rid of, had lots of zucchini so used all that up, and used 2 cups of frozen blueberries.  I baked 2 regular sized loaves for 57 minutes.  Even with all these changes, it was incredible.   I-N-C-R-E-D-I-B-L-E!!!!

None
text:
These are delicious!  The amount of blueberries is generous and fantastic!  I make them in jumbo muffin pans and made several changes to get the total calories down below 350.  First, for the muffins, I cut the sugar to 1 3/4 cups as other reviewers suggested and substituted half of the oil for applesauce.  I'm a sucker for crumb toppings so I used the crumb topping recipe from cookiequeen with a few exceptions.  For my crumb topping used: 2/3 cup flour, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar 1 tsp cinnamon,  1/2 stick softened butter-mixed altogether with hand.  You hardly notice the little cuts and don't have to feel as guilty about eating them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I needed to use up all the zucchini had picked from my garden. This was perfect. But I made several changes to make it healthier. First, I used 1 cup of honey in place of all the sugar. Then I used 2 1/2 cups whole wheat flour in place of all the white flour and 1 cup applesauce (no sugar added) in place of the oil. I also squeezed all the water out of the zucchini (I probably used a little more than two cups, I didn't measure. I just had 5 small zucchini that needed using up) and I added 1/4 cup wheat bran and 2 tbsp wheat germ. I lowered the temperature to 320 degrees (because of the honey) and cooked it in muffin pans. I don't know how long it took to cook. I just used my moms method of checking on them soon as they start smelling really good. Worked perfect! Could maybe be a little sweeter though. Next time I might use a 1/4 cup more honey.

text:
Yummy.  I've eaten it with and without changes noted by others.  This is a favorite for fourth of July events, I bake several loaves and slice them.  Then make a simple blueberry syrup (1 cup blueberries covered with water, 3/4 C sugar simmer until thickened).  I take loaf and syrup to even.  Place on slices on platter. drizzle syrup over slices, add a dollop of whip cream to each slice and garnish with a sliced strawberry.  Red, white, blue and easy!

Absolutely loved it!  Cut the sugar down to 2 cups as recommended; 1 c. white, 1 c. brown.  Added pecans.  Will try using 1/2 applesauce and 1/2 oil to cut fat.  Takes a lot longer to shred zucchini by hand than I thought it would.   2 cups shredded is about 2 medium zucchinis.
I also baked it in 2 loaf pans instead of the minis.  Took about 1 hr 10 mins to cook.
I will also try adding some cranberries next time.  
Overall a very flavorful, moist bread!

text:
Very very yummy. I ended up with a ton of batter (perhaps because I put in about 3 cups zucchini) so I made 5 mini loaves instead of four. I doubted that mini loaves needed 50 minutes to bake so I pulled them out at 37 mintues - that was a mistake. If they look like they're getting too brown on top, just cover them with foil or something and keep them in for longer. The one loaf I've cut into came out all mushy in the center. :( It still tastes amazing! Just not something I'll wrap up and give to friends.

text:
This bread was really good but I admit I didn't make as directed. I used 1/2 cup oil and 1/2 cup applesauce; 1 1/2 cup white sugar and 3/4 cup brown sugar; 1 tablespoon vanilla extract and 1 tablespoon lemon extract. I know that might seem like too much extract but the flavors weren't overpowering. I also used cookiequeen's topping (butter, brown sugar, cinnamon, flour, and walnuts) before baking. It makes a lot but I was able to pack almost all of it on between the two loaves before baking. The lemon flavor was a refreshing addition and went very well with the blueberries of course. Very moist and delicious!

text:
Very good. Personally, i don't like zucchini bread terribly well, but this turned out fantastic. I had a HUGE zucchini, so i ended up using 3.5 cups of shredded/peeled zucchini and it ended up being a wonderful dense bread! Next time, i would cut it back to 3 cups. I also made a brown sugar/white sugar/ cinnamon crust. Somehow my mother ended up getting rid of my loaf pan, so i baked it in an angel-food-cake-pan and it turned out wonderful. 

I also tossed my blueberries in flour before adding them to prevent them from sinking to the bottom.
Can't wait to make again!

text:
I read quite a few of the reviews and then decided to take some of the ideas. I did use 1/2  cup oil and the other 1/2 cup  applesauce. I used  1 1/2 cups each on white flour and whole wheat flour and kept the amount of sugar the same.  I also added a bit more on the zucchini and a 1/4 tsp nutmeg. I floured the blueberries lightly and didn't have the problem with them sticking to the bottom of the pans. This made 2 loaves for me and I used Pam on 1 and greased the other loaf pan with shortening. They both came out no problem but a little easier on the loaf pan using the shortening. This is one of the best blueberry loaves I have made and will continue to be the only one I use now. This is very moist and you don't even know the zucchini is in it. My 17 month old  grandsons devoured this.

text:
I made this in one big pan to yield 16 good-sized pieces (cut like a cake). I replaced half of some ingredients to reduce it from 8 pts (Weight Watchers speak) to 5 pts per serving. 1/2 oil replaced with applesauce. 1/2 white flour replaced with wheat flour. 1/2 sugar replaced with Splenda. Turned out fine. Not as sweet, I'm sure, but good.

Changes I made: frozen blueberries, only 2 cups sugar (half brown, half white), and for the flour, I subbed out one cup with whole wheat pastry flour.  It was delicious!  It baked perfectly, it tastes great without any spread on it, and I am looking forward to playing around with healthier variations, like sweet potato or apple sauce instead of the oil, and possibly replacing more of the white flour, perhaps with oat bran.  This is a great way to use up produce and eat your veggies.  Thanks for a great recipe!

Excellent flavor & texture all around. I used paper mini loaf 'pans' that cost .60 each and baked them on a heavy cookie sheet. They took a bit longer to bake than the recipe, but the toothpick test was easy and accurate. No need to grease the paper pans, they look very nice for gift giving (brown-ish w/a design), and peeled right off the bread without marring it at all.

country:
None
text:
Moist and delicious!! My husband and kids loved this bread.  They are not fans of zucchini and said they wouldn't have even known that there was zucchini in the bread if I didn't tell them. As cookiequeen suggested, I changed up the sugar and used 2 cups white and 1/4 cup brown and added about 1/4 tsp nutmeg. I also added a crumb topping before baking (2/3 c. flour, 1/2 c. brown sugar, 1/2 c. white sugar, 1 tsp. cinnamon, 1/2 c. quick oats mixed together and cut in 1 stick butter).  I made 2 regular sized loaves and cooked for 65 minutes.  Even though I used cooking spray, the loaves stuck a little to the bottom of the pans.  Next time I will line the bottom with parchment paper.

text:
I am giving this recipe five stars instead of four because I feel that after reading the reviews the changes I made may have knocked it down a star or two from the recipe as written.  I used a half cup applesauce in place of half of the oil and I used two cups of King Arthur organic white whole wheat flour and one cup of all purpose flour.  Although the end result was very moist, I could taste the applesauce (I used all natural, no sugar added sauce) and the flavor did not wow me.  Although I thought that 1 Tablespoon of cinnamon was a respectable amount it just wasn’t enough oomph for me.  I made a topping of butter, flour, oats, and cinnamon as other reviewers suggested and I thought it added to the end product both in flavor and appearance.

text:
My husband HATES zucchini. I told him he would like it in bread but he didn't belirve me. He shreaded the zucchini & was in shock when I mixed it in. I found this recipe yesterday & read the reviews. I too did not think blueberries & zucchini would be a good combo, but I trusted the others who have  tried it. WHAT A HIT!!!! oh my gosh!!! SO YUMMY! I went with 1 1/2 c white sugar & 3/4 c. brown. The batter didn't look like what I was expecting...but I didn't make any other changes. I divided the batter in 1/2....1/2 I used frozed/thawed blueberries which were wonderful & 1/2 dried cranberries. I made 1 mini loaf and 4 muffins from each. I'm sure the bread will be great...but we were too full from eating the muffins. Next time I'll try pineapple. Thanks for posting this!

text:
Very yummy recipe!  I really like the blueberries, but they make the loaf runnier than usual and so maybe I will omit them next time I make this.  Also, I baked it in a larger loaf pan, and it was hard to gadge the time and so next time I will try making them into muffins.  I also used only 1.5 cups of sugar, substituting 1/2 of brown sugar.  And I used more zucchini and only 3/4 c of oil.  All in all, it turned out delicious, and I will be definitely making this again!

*2nd Note* I made this again as muffins, and I thought they were even more delicious!  I think the less time it has to spend in the oven, the better!  I baked them for 20 min, and they came out beautifully!

userID:
10304827
Display Name:
Henri-Ann Nortman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
29
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2813114.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love zucchini bread and I love blueberries so I was anxious to try this.  I made it in a bundt pan and it took about 1 hour and 10 minutes to cook.  It turned out beautifully.  I followed many of the suggestions of other commenters to make it a little more healthy.  I used half whole wheat and half white flour.  I used 1/2 cup of greek yogurt and 1/2 cup of oil instead of a full cup of oil.  I cut the cinnamon and vanilla back to 2 tsp each (3 tsp just seemed like it would be too much).  I cut the sugar way back to 1 1/2 cups and it was plenty sweet with that.  I also added the zest of one lemon, because I love the flavors of blueberry and lemon together.  I used fresh blueberries and tossed them in about a tablespoon of flour before folding them in.  They did not rise or sink, but stayed evenly mixed throughout the batter.  Next time, I will add chopped pecans.  I am sure this recipe would be wonderful as muffins.

text:
Excellent recipe.  Extreamly moist.  Used 3 cups of zucchini, substituted in 1/2 cup w. wheat flour, substituted in lemon zest & juice from 1 lemon in place of 1/4 cup of the vegetable oil (since lemon & blueberries are a good combo).  Used 2 cups FROZEN blueberries instead of fresh. I folded them in quickly from the freezer, first coating them with some flour so they don't "bleed" while the loaves are cooking. I also used the crumb topping from most helpful review from "cookiequeen".  That topping was crispy and crumbly without too much sweetness.

text:
This recipe makes LOVELY muffins! I don't own a loaf pan, so I opted to make muffins instead of bread. I did not alter the ingredients in this recipe for the muffins, only the cooking time. I changed the recipe to yield 8 servings, and that made approx a dozen muffins, and I baked them for 20-25 minutes. My BF had never had a baked good with zucchini in it before I made this... he was skeptical at first, but after he tried it, he ate 3 more! I had sat down and had a muffin with a cup of tea and I just couldn't get over how good they were. I think I will prefer to make them as muffins because it's less messy. I will definitely be keeping this recipe on hand and be making it many more times!

I'm glad i waited to rate this recipe bc it is SOOOO totally yummy the day AFTER baking.  didn't have the 4 mini loaf pans so I just used 2 standard size pans.  baked it for about 10 min longer than recipe said bc that was how long it took for my toothpick to come out clean,  the day of baking I thought this bread was good but not spectacular then this morning with coffee I had a slice...YUM!  the blueberries really are the star of the show in this recipe.  so so good! text:
I modified by making this into a bunt cake.

i also:

(1) used 1/2 pint blueberries instead of 1 pint
(2) added 3/4 cup chopped walnuts
(3) shredded the zucchini using a veggie chopper for slightly larger pieces than shredded
(4) baked at 350 for 60 min. instead of 50 min (since i used a Bunt Cake pan)
(5) drizzled a glaze made from vanilla, powdered sugar and milk over the top

doing thus, this turned into THE BEST CAKE i have EVER made.

Delicious bread.  Cut sugar to heaping 1/2 C of white and 1/2 C packed brown, grated 1 small fresh apple for half of the oil and used 2-3 C zucchini, plus a little nutmeg.  Made a crumb topping with 1/2 C flour, sugar and oats, 1 tsp cinnamon and mixed with butter and coconut oil.  Though topping was yummy it was messy, and unneeded. This is a keeper for fresh blueberry season - but seriously you can cut the sugar and it's still sweet.

text:
I subbed the following: a little more than half flour for whole wheat pastry flour, half oil for applesauce, half sugar for Splenda. The extra fiber made it more filling and satisfied my hunger, so one slice with coffee will be enough for breakfast. I used less blueberries (BB) than called for because my BB were huge! I'm so glad I used less! Next time I'll use dried BB because while I like the flavor I didn't like the extra globs of moisture. This will be a staple recipe for me, and will be used in variation  by adding nuts or dried cranberries, pears, etc. I sprinkled the top with a little sugar for a little crispness...the family is going back for seconds as I write this review and my husband hates vegetables!

userID:

Display Name:
fizzyginger

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good bread. As written, this recipe is pretty tasty, although it is very sweet as other reviewers have mentioned. I've made it with 1 cup of the flour replaced with whole wheat, 1/4 of the oil replaced with applesauce, and the sugar reduced by 1/4 cup. Made this way, the bread is still very sweet and moist. Also, this recipe works fine with a pint (2 cups) of frozen blueberries instead of fresh. Finally, this bread freezes well. Once the bread has completely cooled, slice it into thick pieces and freeze in a ziplock bag. Pull one slice out at a time and warm it in a toaster oven for an easy breakfast. It tastes just as good as when it came out of the oven the first time!

Blueberries were a bit expensive so I only bought a little box which didn't seem like enough for me but I happened to have a pomegrante on hand so I broke it open and added the seeds to the batter. The seeds are still a little hard but softend significatly- similar to the texture of adding nuts.  Simply delicious! The batter perfectly made 4 mini loafs- awesome for freezing and bringing out for the holidays and gift giving. I did do 1/2 cup applesauce, 1/2 cup oil and 1 cup white sugar, 1 cup brown sugar and topped with a little large grain white sugar before baking. So with all the fruit and zucchini and 1/2 the oil- this is a pretty healthy snack that even the kids will like! I would give it 10 stars if I could! Thank you for a wonderful recipe!

We have made this recipe so many times and will continue to do so.  I do make changes each time and will continue to do so as cooking for me in an individualized moment-to-moment experience!  To make it healthier we use whole wheat flour, add some walnuts, cut the sugar in almost half and often times we use maple syrup instead.  We generally make it into muffins and ALWAYS add a yummy oatmeal & walnut streusel.  The great thing about this recipe is it is a versatile,fabulous foundation from which you can make it your own!

Very, very tasty.  I did make some changes but I'm sure the original recipe is even better.  I halved the recipe to make one loaf.  I used Egg Beaters for the eggs, 1/4 c. oil & 1/4 c. applesauce. text:
amazing!  I live at high altitude, so I adjusted it a little for that by adding 2T additional of applesauce (I did half and half with oil and applesauce), left out 1T of sugar, and only did 3/4 tsp of baking powder.  I also baked it in 2 large loaf pans at 350 for 1 hr 10 minutes.  ETA:  Not even 24 hours after it came out of the oven, we are well into our second loaf!  This is very yummy!

6/17 - I have made this about 50 times. One thing that I do is grease the loaf pans with shortening and then 'dust' them with a cinnamon/sugar mixture. I also coat the top with the cinnamon/sugar mixture. My high altitude alterations work every time.

None
text:
Delicious -- very moist, good flavor, holds up well next day, and can can be made much healthier without it *tasting* healthier.

I replaced the 1 c veg oil with a cup of fresh apple sauce (just blended up 2 apples, peels on) and a splash of oil.
Decreased the 2 1/4 cup sugar to a bit over 2/3 cup brown sugar and 1/2 cup white sugar (taste the batter to get a sense) and will decrease the sugar some more next time.
Replaced the AP flour with whole wheat pastry flour

I also toss the blueberries in a bit of flour before adding them to help keep them distributed throughout the batter.

I baked them up as muffins in the same temp oven but obviously shorter time.

Yummy! My husband was upset when he saw this recipe- I had promised to make him zucchini bread, but I wanted to try this. I promised him the next batch would be regular zucchini bread. Well, after tasting it- he said not to make anything with our zucchini except this bread!! I myself was WOWED. I will be taking this to all our "bring something" get togethers. update: I used the crumb topping, and it was delish, but be warned- it makes the bread much heavier tasting. Mu husband says he prefers no crumb topping.

text:
Wow! This is fabulous! I too had the skeptical husband...I am sure he thought I was wasting the fresh blueberries HE PICKED. I followed some of the suggestions and my changes were as follows:
Oil (used 3/4 cup applesauce 1/4 oil)
Sugar (used 3/4 cup brown sugar & 1/2 evaporated cane juice)
Flour (used 2 cups whole wheat & 1 cup white)
ADDED 1/4 cup ground flax seed
Doubled blueberries
Topped with the mix of cinnamon, brown sugar, white sugar, nutmeg.
Delicous and moist! 
Hubby had one warm piece out of the oven and then asked for more!

I used whole wheat flour, and 2 larger loaf pans as opposed to the 4 minis.  Next time I will sub half oil for applesauce as some people did, and make muffins.  Definitely keeping this recipe! :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe would be great as written and I will definitely be making as written if I give these as gifts, but for our household, I chose to make 12 muffins and modified the recipe to make them healthier. The modifications were as follows:
Used a little less than 1 cup of the commercial Splenda/brown sugar mix (1/2 cup is equal to the sweetness of 1 full cup), used 3 cups of zucchini (squeezed of excess liquid), used 1 cup of whole wheat flour and 2 cups of nutri-flour (like normal all purpose flour but has a higher fiber content).  I also used 1 cup of applesauce instead of the oil. Finally, I used frozen blueberries and tossed them in flour before folding them into the mixed ingredients.  The muffins baked for around 40 minutes. These were great even with all the healthy modifications.

text:
I've made this a few times and it's always great. It freezes well too; so it's great to make in the summer and freeze it for a winter treat. I do make it healthier by using 1/2 c oil and 1/2 c Apple sauce. I use 1/2 whole wheat pastry flour and 1/2 unbleached flour. I also just use 1 1/2 c sugar, sometimes I mix white and brown.  I don't mesure my zuchini, but use a medium one. I ran out of vanilla so I used 1/2 vanilla and 1/2 almond extract. I like extra blueberries. And it was awesome!!! Depending on your tastes, the cinnamon may be too much. Be sure to Greece the pans well.

This reviewer added a crumb topping which I also added. Without the topping, I think the bread would have been a bit bland. Also, if the loaf sits a day or two it tastes even better so don't hesitate to make this recipe ahead of time. 
Next time I am  going to to try and and the crumb topping in the middle of the bread (pour 1/2 batter in loaf pan, add topping, pour second half batter in pan and add more topping! Love the topping. 
I made 24 of these loaves and froze most of them. They freeze very, very well and I think taste even better after being frozen.

text:
So good, this will be my "go to" recipe now. Nice and moist but not too moist, I didn't get to try it warm but it is very good refridgerated. I did make two small changes though. First was I quickly found out that I apparently don't have ANY bread pans so I used a 13x9 glass baking dish (it would be great as muffins too), also instead of 2-1/4 cups of white sugar I used 2 cups and then sprinkled the top with about a 1/4c of brown sugar which I HIGHLY recommend (it gives it just that little bit of crunch that it needs). The recipe doesn't mention this but zucchini has a lot of liquid when you shred it so it needs to be drained or shredded right into a strainer over a bowl or something.

This recipe deserves the awesome rating it has!  Like a lot of other people, I made a few modifications.  First, I used frozen zucchini and blueberries from last summer (thawed).  Second, I used 1/2 and 1/2 white/whole wheat flour.  I also halved the sugar and used 1/2 and 1/2 applesauce and oil.  I made them into muffins, baked about 25 minutes at 350.  These were great just out of the oven and even better cold the next morning, which is rarely the case with muffins.  Stop reading reviews and try it!!!

This is my new fav for berry muffins...I use the recipe as above with reduced sugar and sub coconut oil and add walnuts and whatever berries I have, fresh or frozen. I have a large garden and chickens, and have found that I can freeze the oil, eggs and shredded zucchini together in a zip-loc bag at the high time of production and only have to add dry ingredients for quick muffins full of good garden stuff all through the winter. Cook muffins 25 minutes or so at 350.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG!!!  Had an abundance of zucchini and blueberries were on sale.  Had a bridge game in the horizon and decided we girls deserved a treat.  And what a treat it was!  LAUJRA, your recipe is a great base.  Just about anything is possible.  After reading several reviews, I found Red Hat Milli's making it into a bundt cake -- what a great idea.  Using her comments along with others, my chances:  subbed 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce for 1/2 cup oil, used only 1 1/2 cups sugar, half my flour was whole wheat, and upped the baking powder to 1 tablespoon (misread the comment that said 3 tablespoons).  Almost cut back on the amount of cinnamon, but given the amount of dry ingredients decided to use the full amount.  Good decision.  Something to think about:  Beat the liquid ingredients with the sugar, and then fold in the dry ingredients until just well mixed.  You'll avoid a tough product that way, be it bread, cake or muffins.  There was just the perfect amount of sweetness and spice.  I had baked it the day before serving and stored it in on a cake server (the kind with the plate for the cake and a lid for the plate).  When I removed the lid before serving the aroma was enough to kill for.  Unfortunately, this is not as healthy as I would like.  Even with using healthier ingredients, the calories only shrinked to 339 calories (assuming 12 servings); but given bridge players and their very unhealthy eating habits, I won't be hesitant to serve this again.  Again, great recipe.

It's hard to decide how many stars to give a recipe after you've tweaked it. But since I really didn't make any drastic changes, I'll give it 5 stars. I used half white and half brown sugar and also used half white and half wheat flour. I would have cut the oil down if I had applesauce but I'm happy to say that the bread was not greasy. This was even a hit with a picky eater!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fantastic.  I cut the ingredients in half for one loaf.  I've used fresh and frozen blueberries and didn't notice a difference.

I've made this a bunch of times now so I can comment on making it healthier.  First, if you use whole wheat flour, do half whole wheat and half white.  All whole wheat doesn't taste right.  You can get away with 2/3 whole wheat also.

Second, you can't really overdo the zucchini.  I always use one medium sized one and grate it.  If you want it to totally disappear in the bread, puree  it.  Otherwise you'll see little flecks in the bread.

Third, use applesauce instead of oil.  It tastes better, and doesn't get as soggy after a day or so.  It's also much healthier.

Finally, store it in the fridge.  It goes bad fast in the heat, and if you made it with whole wheat flour, it'll spoil even faster.  It's not as good cold but you can always zap it in the microwave for 15 seconds.

text:
Great recipe!  Added chopped walnuts (about a cup) and a crumble topping (basic, flour/brown sugar/butter).  For anyone else wondering about the mini-loaf thing: it filled 6 of mine, which is the equivalent of 2 standard-sized loaves.  I baked them for 43 minutes total and they turned out great.  I'll also grease & flour my next pans (though they were non-stick).  I just Pam'd these and removal was tricky -- blueberries, once baked, become sticky to get out of the pan.  Wonderful gifts for neighbors for the holiday-tween times though.  Thanks for the recipe!

This is the best bread EVER!!! I've made this 4 times in 2 weeks. I made it per recipe and with changes for lower calorie and u can't tell the difference. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made some changes.  Substituted the 1 c. oil for 1/2 c. oil and 1/2 c. applesauce. Substituted 2 1/4 c. sugar with 2 c. sugar and 1/4 c. brown sugar.  Everything else stayed the same for the bread, plus added extra blueberries because I have no clue what a pint looks like, so I am sure I over compensated for my lack of knowledge!  In the pan before adding the mixture, I greased it and put in a mixture of 1 tsp each of cinnamon, sugar, and brown sugar and a 1/2 tsp. nutmeg.  Shook it around like flour.  And I made a crumb topping with 1/4 each of oatmeal, sugar, and flour, a tsp. of cinnamon, and a few tbs. of butter to make it crumbly, sprinkled on top and put in the oven.  I also made it in 2 large loaf pans and bakes for 1 hour 20 minutes.  Came out perfect.  This was my first Zucchini bread ever, and I just took off what 5 other reviews said and put it all in one.  Turned out SO GREAT!!!!  Can't wait to share it with the family and then next time figure how to make it healthier!

I am gluten intolerant, and I changed this recipe to my gluten-free all purpose flour with 1 1/2 tsp xantam gum added. I used 1/2 cup oil and 1/2 cup applesauce and 1 tsp nutmeg. Remainder of ingredients used as listed. I baked it for 1 1/2 hours at 350 degress. This cake came out moist and flavorful. Baking gluten free is not easy and this recipe came out Fabulous. text:
I love this recipe, so different than the usual zucchini recipes. I wanted to use up some frozen rhubarb, so I substituted it for the blueberries. I tossed them with 1/3 c brown sugar to downplay the tartness and then in 1/3 c flour to prevent them from sinking. It turned out amazing, but there was not a hint of tartness, so I may cut down the brown sugar next time to give a little zing.

I just made this super moist and tasty- and a great way to use freshly picked blueberries and those giant zucchinis from the garden.  

I made some changes: I added amaretto liquor, and cut back the vanilla.  I also added nutmeg and allspice, to make a more spicy bread.  And I used Earth Balance instead of the vege oil.  Finally, I added a simple strudel to the top made from flour, earth balance, brown sugar and cinnamon.  This kicked it up a notch.  Yum.

text:
What a great recipe.  The other night I wanted to bake something and couldn't decide if I wanted to bake with blueberries or zucchini as I had just picked both.  So I went searching on this site and found this recipe that uses both ingredients.  It was the best thing I could have done.  I made it in 2 reg. loaf pans and baked for 1 hr. 20 min.  I kept one loaf for us and sent one to a relative.  My husband was upset that I gave away a loaf.  So I made the recipe again and this time I made 24 muffins, topped with brown sugar/cinnamon mixture.  Brought some to work and they were a big hit.  Would recommend this recipe 100%.

Possibly the best zucchini bread I've had! The blueberries add such a nice, moist touch and I don't know if I'll ever be able to enjoy zucchini bread without them now. I cut back on the sugar and will cut it back further to about 1 1/2 cups next time; also like others used half oil half applesauce and 1 cup of whole wheat pastry flour. I made two regular size loafs and they cooked in just under one hour. I froze one loaf and it was just as good a week later.

region:

country:

text:
Delicious! I followed a couple recommendations and replaced 1/2 the oil with apple sauce, and it was still moist. It's a little sweet, so probably could reduce the sugar a bit. This made 3 of the 4.5" x 8.625" foil loaf pans for me. Make sure you only fill 2/3 full, because they do rise. Took 70 minutes in my toaster oven.  I didn't see this mentioned earlier, but you shred the zucchini with the skin on. I used a cheese grater, and it worked perfectly. Two 6-inch zucchinis make the 2 cups. You can freeze after shredding to have some on hand all the time.

text:
This was the most delicious homemade bread EVER! I kept everything the same except I substituted half the oil for applesauce and used canola oil for the other half rather than vegetable oil. Also used half unbleached flour, half whole wheat flour. So incredibly moist! I had enough mix to fill five mini loaf pans and didn't need to cook any longer than instructed, they were perfect. Best right out of the oven with some butter, YUM!

text:
This is a really wonderful moist bread. I followed the recipe except I used frozen blueberries (slightly thawed, rinsed, & drained.) I made it into 2 regular size loaf pans, since I don't own any mini loaf pans. My husband thought zucchini and blueberry together didn't sound very good together, but after tasting it said I should make a loaf for him to share with his co-workers. I did add a crumble mixture to the top also because my family loves breads that way. I used a mixture of oats, flour, cinnamon, chopped walnuts, and a little brown sugar and butter. My mother-in-law also really enjoyed this. Will make again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2567820.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!  I used 1 1/2 cup all-purpose, 1 cup oat and 1/2 cup whole wheat flour,  1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce and 1/2 cup oil, and used 1 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup brown.  I made in one large loaf pan and baked for about an hour total, doing a toothpick test until done.  Since I reduced the overall sugar, I ended up with a less sweet bread, which was what I was hoping for - you could certainly used the recommended amount of sugar if you like it sweet.  Also, I like others' recommendations of subbing a little brown sugar - makes for a slightly crunchy crust.

text:
Yummy!  I will surely make this again. I decided to make this today because I had some zucchini and blueberries that I needed to use.   I took some of the advice from other reviewers and used 2 C. white sugar and 1/4 C. brown sugar; 1/2 C. oil and 1/2 C. applesauce; and 2 C. all-purpose flour and 1 C. wheat flour.  I almost forgot about the topping:  1/2 C. brown sugar and 1/2 C. white sugar and a stick of butter.  I waited to put the topping on until there was about 20 minutes left.  My four mini loaves were done after 45 minutes.

text:
YUM! YUM! Double triple dog YUM! Recipe is easy to assemble, forgiving, and chock full of moisture and berries.  Like most others that made this recipe I tweaked it suit my needs by adding two small bananas and cutting oil in half.  For some reason I had enough for five mini pans (banana addage?) and the cooking time was increased slightly by five to seven mins.  I would definitely make these again!

text:
I adapted this recipe because I wanted to use up my unsweetened applesauce and wanted my bread to have a lemon taste with no cinnamon to dominate that flavor.  So the used about 3/4 cup of applesauce and filled the rest of the one cup message with veggie oil.  Then I added 1 TBS of grated fresh lemon zest to the liquid ingredients.  My batter made four mini loafs and 2 jumbo muffins.  I also made Cookie Queens review on here for a crumble topping, but used a lot of lemon zest instead of cinnamon and pecans instead of walnuts.  It was the best zucchini bread I have ever tasted and I am a avid baker!  Great base recipe!  Blueberries and lemon with zucchini are heavenly!  I will make again for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great!  I took some tips from other reviewers and reduced the white sugar to 1 1/2 cups and added 1/2 cup of brown sugar.  I reduced the oil to 1/2 cup and added 1/2 cup of applesauce. I also added 1/4 t. nutmeg to the batter and used frozen blueberries instead of fresh after  tossing them  in a little flour so that they wouldn't sink to the bottom of the pan. I baked the bread in a bundt pan that I greased and sprinkled with a combination of 1 t. white sugar, I t. brown sugar, 1 t. cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg - shaking off the excess.  I baked for an hour and 15 minutes and it came out perfectly.  Our bumper crop of zucchini will be put to good use this year since I will definitely be making this again!

text:
Love this recipe. I used gluten free flour, 1 1/4 cups brown sugar + 1 white and added some nutmeg. Baked in two 4x8 pans for 1 hour & 20 mins and they came out perfect. I tried one non-stick pan lightly oiled and a tin-foil pan also oiled - both loaves came out easily after 20 min. rest but definitely prefer the easy cleaning with the tin foil! I made a streusel topping but made the mistake of making too much and the top was pretty hard/crunchy! The flavor of the loaf is spot-on though :)
Note: I used two packed cups of well-drained zucchini but did not use the salt/weep method - just squeezed it out in a dish towel.

text:
WOW!! This is incredible. I followed the recipe exactly except I did flour my blueberry before adding so they not sink. I also did half oil and half applesauce (I do this with most my baking to help keep it moist). The smell while baking was incredible-I wanted to eat it right then. 

I made a few mini loaves (5X3 1/4) which took 50 minutes--it didn't look like it was baking until the last 10 minutes. I also made a couple  8X4 loaves which took a bit longer than the 50 min--not sure how much more as I used the clean knife test. Half way through I rotated my pans half way around. Did not open the oven any other time until timer went off. I know some reviews say their bread was soggy and mushy--not mine. Nice and moist and the crispy crunchy outer that all my breads have. I will admit as I started to mix ingredients together I was worried as it was soupy when I added the zucchini. It thickened up a little bit when adding the flour mixture but, it baked wonderfully. 

I did not squeeze or drain my zucchini. I shredded it right before using it. I also kept the skin on as more nutritional value. You can see flecks of green in the bread. It does have more of a blueberry than zucchini taste in my opinion. 

I did forget to grease my pans but had no problem when slicing and taking out--no sticking at all. 

This is a keeper and I know I will be making more.

text:
The BEST zucchini bread that my family as ever tasted.  The blueberries are the perfect compliment.  There is only one change to the recipe that I made: instead of using all-purpose flour + salt + baking powder + baking soda, I used 3 cups of self-rising flour.  It made all the difference in the world AND cut down on unnecessary work.  I recommend this recipe to all of you.

text:
These turned out delicious!! I made them as written and they are moist, not too sweet, and a great way to use up garden goodness. I quadrupled the recipe since I had 5 lbs of blueberries, 2 huge zucchini, and 1 giant yellow squash to use up. From the quadrupled recipe, I yielded 6 loaves, 24 muffins, and 48 mini muffins. The loaves baked about 55 mins in my oven, the muffins about 25 mins, and the mini muffins about 15-20 mins. I will be freezing most of these for use through the winter or to give as last minute gifts. The hard part will be keeping my husband and kids away from them while they finish cooking!!

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe is great - after reading reviews I must comment. Please DO NOT drain the zucchini.  Zucchini is inherently watery, which is what is considered when making any zucchini bread.  The water is there for the moisture. You can add more zucchini without ruining the recipe, but do not drain, squeeze out, salt or otherwise reduce the liquid.  It will not be as good. This is a great combo - delicious bread as is, or with sugar or applesauce changes. But just because it has vegetables in it does not make it healthy.  Flour and sugar in near equal amounts is not healthy....delicious yes, healthy no.  Enjoy this because it is good.  It's not a healthy diet food.

text:
These are great!  I didn't have applesauce but wanted to cut the sugar and oil so I mashed up a ripe banana and used 3/4 cup of oil and 1 cup and a half of sugar. I haven't used zucchini before, so I appreciate others suggesting how to get the water out.  I grated a large zucchini and used all of it.  Putting the grated zucchini in a dish towel to squeeze out the water worked very well!  I put the batter in muffin cups and baked for 25-27 mins in the oven.  They turned out very good!  Made 22 medium sized muffins.

Absolutely terrific!! As many others suggested, I used 1/2 oil and 1/2 applesauce, 1/2 white flour and 1/2 whole wheat. Love this!!!! Followed the recipe to the letter the first time --- yummy! Then I made muffins from this --- moist and delicious. Since I do not have the time to bake every morning, I froze the muffins individually with a vacuum food system in plastic bags using the pulse/gentle setting as not to crush the muffin. Before going to bed, I put a frozen muffin on the counter and microwave 15 seconds to warm it the next morning.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6172238.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is  a very moist and flavorful zucchini bread! It's not too dense and has a really good texture. I will definitely save this recipe and make it again. I tweaked it slightly according to some suggestions, but these are minor. I used coconut oil instead of veggie oil, 2 Cups of sugar, and only 1 Tablespoon of cinnamon. I also cut back on the blueberries as I used a heaping cup instead (maybe about 1.5 cups). 
I used two regular sized bread pans and divided the batter between them. It cooked for the recommended time and then about 5 min. more, but just watch it so that you don't over cook it.  The batter would probably fit in one regular pan, but I think you would have a longer cook time. 
The bread popped right out of the pan (don't over cook and allow it to sit for the full 20 min before moving to a wire rack.)

text:
YUM!!!! After reading a bunch of reviews.. I made the following changes..
- 3 cups shredded zuccini, measured then drained/squeezed to get rid of water (instead of 2C Zucc)
- 1 C white, 1 C brown sugar (instead of 2 1/4 C white sugar)
- 1/3C oil, 2/3C applesauce (instead of 1C oil)
- 1 1/2  tsp baking soda (instead of 1 tsp)
- 1 tsp cinnamon (instead of 1T cinnamon)
So good, my 7yo picky daughter loved it and said it's the best muffin! My 5yo super non veggie child got turned off by the zucchini. :( maybe I will peel the skin next time I make it so there's no green showing..

Display Name:
Lieselotte

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe to the "T" the first time and it was pretty good a little sugary but good however the second time I decided to shake it up a bit and change a few things including one of the main ingredients! When it came to the oil a full cup seemed like an awful lot to me so instead of one cup of vegetable oil I did a half cup of apple sauce and a half cup of coconut oil. for the sugar I reduced the white sugar down to one cup and added a 1/2 cup of brown sugar.  lastly, I didn't feel like blueberries this time and wanted to go a naughtier route so I replaced them with chocolate chips.  after I poured the batter into my loaf pans I sprinkled the top with a little sugar in the raw.  These modifications to an already top notch recipe turned out to be the most decadently rich dessert I have ever had!  super moist and absolutely irresistible!!!!

None
text:
Yum! Love this recipe with the healthier alterations I made. I use melted coconut oil instead of veg oil, only ONE cup of sugar (that's where I took away one star. It calls for way more sugar than necessary), milled flaxseed mixed with water to replace eggs, and whole wheat flour instead of white all-purpose.
Just to note: the batter will slightly solidify if using coconut oil and frozen blueberries, making it a bit more challenging to get into the pans (you kinda have to press it in) but it all softens again once in the oven and turns out fine :)

text:
Great recipe, definite keeper!  I made with slightly less sugar, used frozen blueberries (thawed for a little while) and I sprinkled 2 T white sugar and 2 T brown sugar mix on top, an idea from another review. I put the zucchini in completely wet without drying off at all.  I used 1/2 batter for one normal size loaf (350 for 50 mins) and the other half made 12 muffins to save time(350 at 18 mins).  Both turned out fantastic!

text:
YUMMY!!  I hadn't had zucchini bread since I was a kid, and this didn't disappoint.  I tried it ALMOST as written for the first time, the only things I changed was I added 1/4 tsp. nutmeg, and I tossed the blueberries in flour.  After mixing the batter, I was a little nervous, because it was significantly denser than most quick breads I'm used to, so I was worried I had made a mistake.  I went ahead an baked them and they turned out yummy.  I did the mini loaves, and came out with 4 beautiful loaves.  I do see the simplicity of changing this recipe up to meet not only tastes, but health preferences, and sizes - Hubby said he thought he'd prefer these as muffing, 'cause then he could have a whole thing instead of just a slice ;)

text:
This bread is great! It was moist, sweet, and not too dense. I never would have thought that blueberries and zucchini would taste good together, but I had some extra zucchinis from my garden and thought I'd give it a try. I made some changes to make it healthier- 1/2 applesauce + 1/2 oil, egg substitute, 1c. sugar + 1c. splenda, and half the flour whole. The batter made 12 regular-sized muffins and two mini- loaves. I'll definitely use this recipe again!

Really enjoyed this bread/cake! Just made it tonight. text:
I did make three small changes but not drastic ones.  For all recipes that call for white flour I split it half white and half wheat (this time I did spelt flour so it wasn't quite as chewy as wheat).  I used half white, half brown sugar and cut it to 2 total cups.  I can back off a little more next time especially if my blueberries are not quite so tart.  I also went down to two teaspoons of cinnamon.  I think the recipe would have been great without my changes.  I made them for our personal preferences.

text:
Best bread ever! Other than using half white flour/half white whole wheat flour, plus 1/2 apple sauce & 1/2 cup oil vs. 1 cup oil (just for a healthier alternative) I didn't change a thing. I didn't have mini loaf pans, so baked in 2 regular loaf pans for 1 hr 20 mins. I made the streusel suggested by cookiequeen in her review and topped 1 of the loaves with it, leaving the second one plain (note: cookiequeen's recipe makes a lot of topping. Next time I will half the recipe). Both loaves were amazing, although I prefer the plain one. My sweet-toothed family; however, loved the one with the streusel topping. Both were gone by the end of the day and my mother-in-law requested it for a mountain getaway. Thank you for posting. Love finding recipes that truly work.

text:
Delicious recipe whether you like zucchini or not.  I made this into 24 muffins which baked for 25 min. Used lots of cinnamon which we love.  To increase the healthy aspect of the ingredients without changing the flavour, I substituted the flour with a whole wheat + white flour blend.  I used half the oil and added applesauce until batter was the right texture.  I also used "Sun Crystals" a stevia/cane sugar blend instead of white sugar.  Turned out great!  Thanks for this, will definitely make again.

None
country:
None
text:
This is excellent.  I didn't change anything except added some extra blueberries.  I baked in 2 large loaf pans for about 1 hr 15 min or till toothpick came clean.  My husband told me never to make regular zucchini bread again.  This also freezes well. Note if you add extra berries be sure to grease your pan well or they may stick and tear the loaf on the bottom when removing from pan.  
Pam baking spray did not work well with this.  Better to stick to conventional pan greasing methods.

text:
I had fresh blueberries to use, so I gave this recipe a shot-AMAZING. Dont even taste the zucchini, what a healthy way to keep this moist! I make this in muffin pans and throw a couple in ziploc bags and throw them in the freezer for breakfast or snacks on the go-just pop them in the microwave and they are yummy and warm all over again.   I used the recipe again with frozen blueberries, and it tasted amazing even still. Good to know i can make this all winter long. This is something I have to have in the freezer at all times!  -I also tried this recipe but added chocolate syrup, melted chocolate (unsweetened and bittersweet) and some mini chocolate chips-it was great! But i definitely think we love this with berries the best. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Similar texture to banana bread.  I substituted 1c. frozen blueberried for fresh, decreased sugar to only have 1/4c. white sugar, 1/2c. packed brown sugar, 1/2c. splenda.  I also followed others and substituted half the oil for unsweetened applesauce, used half unbleached white flour and half whole wheat flour and decreased salt to 1/2tsp.  I thought this bread had great flavor and I will make it again (just with the healthier adjustments I made).

userID:
2428837
Display Name:
Jan
isPro:

16
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews, this recipe was modified quite a bit from the original.  I used 1/2 cup vegetable oil, 1/2 cup applesauce, 1 tsp vanilla extract (use the real thing, please), 1 cup white sugar, 3/4 cup packed brown sugar, 3 cups zucchini (left in a sieve to drain), and a bag of defrosted blueberries. Baked in two regular sized loaf pans.  Topped them with a crumb topping made up of 1/3 cup packed brown sugar, 2 tbsp flour, 1/4 tsp cinnamon, and 1 tbsp butter. Baked both pans at 350 for 1 hr.  Even after reducing the sugar and adding the crumb topping, it was still sweet so do not put in 2 1/4 cups sugar.  This bread is very moist and delicious.

text:
I have a bumper crop of zucchini so I have been experimenting with a variety of zucchini recipes.  This once was excellent! I increased the amount of zucchini by 1 cup, substituted 1-1/2 cups of organic unsweetened apple sauce for the cup of oil, used 2 cups of brown sugar instead of white and added more blueberries. The result was a delicious moist cake rather than a bread. Kids will love it as you cannot detect the zucchini at all!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe  and after reading some of the reviews, I substituted half whole wheat flour and half applesauce for the oil, upped the zucchini to 3 cups and reduced some of the sugar.  I baked the batter in two regular sized loaf pans and knew I had to increase the baking time but wasn't sure how much longer to bake the loaves.  One reviewer stated 70 minutes and another said to bake them for one hour twenty minutes.  I kept checking for doneness and after almost an hour and  a half, the tester looked like it was coming out clean and I was afraid the outside of the loaves would start burning if I left them in any longer so I took them out of the oven and let them cool.  Mu daughter came up to try some and cut a piece for herself and for me and the centre still seemed kind of doughy although we still ate it and it did  taste wonderful.  I don't know what went wrong.  The batter did seem kind of thin so I'm wondering if there was too much water in the zucchini.  I still gave the recipe 5 stars because the bread tasted so good.  I'll try it again and this time I'll try to squeeze out as much water as  I can out of the zucchini to see if that makes a difference.

I would give 4 1/2 stars. :) This was a good recipe. I used half applesauce , half oil to cut down on the fat and also 3/4 tsp almond extract and some freshly ground nutmeg to the mix. I used 2 1/2c white flour and 1/2c whole wheat flour. I topped it with some strudel made out of butter, brown sugar, a bit of flour, and a little cinnamon. I had enough for 5 mini loaves and baked for 50 minutes. Its a good way to get veggies and fruit.

This was delicious!  As recommended by other reviewers, I also made some substitutions..1/2 cup unsweet applesauce and 1/2 cup canola oil for the oil, 1/2 whole wheat and 1/2 all-purpose flour and only used 1 1/2 cups sugar.  I made 2 dozen muffins with this mix and sprinked a little white/brown sugar mix over the top before baking.  Baked for about 25 minutes.  This recipe is great and will be used many times again!

text:
Wonderful bread!  I just ate a warm muffin, and it was so delicious!  I would love to make the recipe as written, but I've recently lost 30 lbs., and want to keep it off!  So, like many others I used 1/2 applesauce and 1/2 canola oil, and I used 1 cup Splenda and 3/4 cup brown sugar, instead of the 2 1/4 cups of white sugar called for in the recipe.  I used frozen blueberries.  It made 8 mini loaves and 6 muffins.  I'm going to freeze the mini loaves and take them as a snack for the grandkids on a camping trip this weekend.

text:
I used 6 egg whites, 1/2 c. of vegetable oil, 1/2 c. organic applesauce in place of some of the oil, 3/4 c. Splenda, 1 large mashed over-ripe banana in place of part of the sugar, all whole wheat flour and two tsp. each of baking powder and baking soda. I made one medium loaf and 12 muffins. My kids thought the muffins were great, I did gift the loaf and can't wait to hear what our neighbor thinks. Next time, I might add some orange zest and maybe some cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla extract. NOTE: I did smush the zucchini inbetween several layers of paper towels to drain the excess liquid. That helped quite a bit.

text:
This is really good and oh sooo moist!  I used 1 1/4 c. white sugar and 1 1/4 c. light brown sugar, which was 1/4 c. more sugar than the recipe called for. I cut the cinnamon to 1 tsp, which I thought was plenty. I didn't have any mini loaf pans so I baked in two bread pans. Wasn't sure what to make a topping of, so I just sprinkled a little brown sugar on top.I had to bake longer than 50 minutes, but I lost track of how much longer. I just kept testing it with a toothpick untill it seemed done liked a cake. The blueberries and zucchini sounded like a odd combo, but was supprisingly good.

text:
This is a delicious recipe.  The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars was because I felt that the amount of cinnamon overpowered the bread a little bit.  I would reduce it at least by half next time. I made two normal sized loaves and they ended up taking closer to 1 hour, 20 minutes. (!)  I also did half white, half whole wheat flourr (which I highly recommend!) and substituted half of the oil with unsweetened applesauce.  I also ommitted 1/4 of the sugar and probably could have left out even more - it was still plenty sweet.  Always looking for ways to make recipes more healthy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A really lovely bread--so delicious! Kudos to Laujra! I made the recipe according to "cookiequeen"'s (Jul. 26, 2006) modifications, and I made a few other modifications myself: 1) I used half canola oil and half roasted hazelnut oil, which I think gave the bread a nice depth of flavor; 2) instead of the dash of nutmeg "cookiequeen" suggested, which I didn't have, I threw in a few dashes of pumpkin pie spice; and 3) to make it vegan, I subbed boxed egg replacer as well as some apple pureed with water (for moistness--a half cup of applesauce would also do) to replace the eggs, and I used vegan cold-pressed (non-trans-fat) margarine instead of the butter for cookiequeen's scrumptious crumb topping. Eight mini-loaves took 35 minutes to bake in my oven. Thanks! My friends, family, and I are all enjoying these delicious little loaves.

text:
So good and so moist!  You'd never know there is zucchini in this bread!  I subbed half the oil with unsweetened apple sauce and decreased the sugar to 1 3/4 cups.  I also added an extra cup of zucchini.  I like to peel my zucchini so the little ones don't see the green specks.  I topped mine with an easy streusel topping to give it a little extra crunch.  I combined 1/2 cup flour, 1/2 cup brown sugar, two tablespoons of butter and a few dashes of cinnamon.  I sprinkled it over the bread before baking.  This recipe made one full sized loaf plus one six-inch cake pan.  I baked the cake pan for about an hour, while the loaf pan took about 70+ minutes to bake.

text:
Followed the recipie as is and wouldn't change a thing.  A great way to use up the extra zucchini from the garden.  The bread is VERY moist and freezes well.  If freezing, I highly recommend placing the bread on a baking sheet in the freezer for a few hours first.  Once bread has formed a 'brick' use a food saver bag that sucks out any remaining air before storing for good.

text:
These were WONDERFUL! I "healthified" them as usual, with the following modifications: used 1 1/3 all purp flour, 1 c whole wheat flour, 1/3 cup buckwheat flour, and 1/3 ground oats (oat flour). I also added 1/4 cup ground flaxseed AND 1/4 cup oat bran. I used the juice AND rind of 1 lemon (my modifications made the dough thicker and stickier, so I needed additional liquid). I love lemon and blueberries together! Even with all of these changes, the texture and taste were out of this world .. even my husband, who doesn't care for baked sweets, ate 4 of them soon after they came out of the oven!!

text:
I made this recipe exactly as written and my family and friends went wild.  After making it several times in one week due to a bumper crop of zuchinni I did make a few changes.  I doubled the recipe and got 5 regular loaves of bread.  When I doubled the recipe I reduced the oil to 1 1/3 cup and it did not change the bread texture or taste but made me feel healthier.  Great recipe and now the first one I reach for when zucchini is out of control!

text:
This recipe is excellent - a great way to use up zucchini from the garden.  I did make a few minor changes as others did:  only added 2 cups of sugar, 1/2 c applesauce, 1/2 c canola oil and equal parts white and wheat flour.  I also made it in a bundt pan and baked at 350* for 1 hour.  The taste and texture are wonderful and I will definitely make this recipe again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The bread is delicious in-and-of-itself, and truly does not need the "topping" suggested by other reviewers. However, if you choose to add the topping, a word of warning . . . the batter fills these mini-loaf pans to the very top, and the bread mounds nicely (almost overflowing) over the tops of the pans. IF you add the topping, it may be too much for the loaves to hold, so consider a fifth mini-loaf pan to hold all that batter and topping.

country:

text:
I made this as written however, I baked in two glass bread pans.  I had to increase the cook time to about 65 minutes.  My husband liked this but the kids and I didn't care for it.  I like the idea of adding fruit and veggies to bread however, I didn't feel like this flavor combo worked for me.  The blueberries were good by themselves however added to such a sweet zucchini bread, they tasted very tart in the mix.  I also thought that maybe too much zucchini was used and made the bread too moist.  A day or two after making this, the bread was mushy and had a lot of liquid seeping from it.  I typically make zucchini bread with just 1 cup grated zucchini.  With the addition of fruit, I don't think 2 cups of zucchini is needed.  I prefer the traditional zucchini bread however I may try again with sweetened fruits and less zucchini.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone likes this bread.  It's very moist.  I often use frozen shredded zucchini (thaw and squeeze out water first) and blueberries.  Also, I subbed apple sauce for half the oil and use a little less sugar.  As one review suggested, I also mixed up some flour, sugar, cinnamon, oats, & butter to make a crumble for the top (about 1-1.5 Tbsp of each).  It can make 2 full loaves of bread instead of the 4 small ones the recipe calls for if you prefer larger loaves.

This bread was amazing!! Like eating zucchini bread and blueberry muffins at the same time. The first loaf was gone in a day! Thanks for the great recipe! Update: I like my loaves a bit bigger so I changed the servings to 16 (still easy to measure) and baked in two 9x5 pans. This serving size gives you a loaf that tops the pan. I baked mine for 1 hr, 20 min, but I would check them a few minutes earlier. Trust me, you'll appreciate the extra because this is incredibly yummy bread & it goes fast!

I might try applesauce next time in place of some of the oil and maybe cut the sugar with a part of Splenda.  We'll see!

text:
Very good recipe! 

I made muffins, here is what I did differently-

I used 3 tsp. of baking powder, although less would have still been okay I think.

I substituted half the oil with 2 mashed bananas (which I had in the freezer and just defrosted for 55 seconds.)

I used a little more zucchini- about 2.5 cups. 

Baked for about 23 minutes. I made 18 large muffins and 12 mini muffins.

At first I wasn't so sure about them, but once they cooled down they were great!!

This bread is excellent!  My husband and I loved it so much that I made another batch a week later.  I did make one loaf in a standard size bread pan which came out fine but I had to cook it longer (about 15 minutes).  Because the bread is so moist, it made it difficult to cut the larger loaf so the next time I stuck with the mini loaf pans.  Either way, it was delicious.

text:
Very good recipe with no changes at all.  I made these into 22 muffins, baking them for 30 minutes - until the tops were lightly browned.  They came out perfectly.  When properly cooled, the top was crunchy and the inside texture was very nice. Okay. So I cheated and ate the first one warm and fresh out of the oven.  I like the idea of another person who suggested adding a pinch of nutmeg to this recipe.  I think I'll do that the next time.  In the meantime, I'll simply eat all the ones I've already made...or perhaps I'll share them. There's no way anyone is going to know there is zucchini in these muffins unless they spy a speck of green here and there! :-)

This recipe is definitely a keeper but will probably add less blueberries and more zucchini next time.  I did as others suggested and used 1 cup of unsweetened applesauce instead of the oil and did 1 cup sugar and 1 cup of splenda.  I also omitted the cinnamon but that is just because of my personal preference.  All in all a great recipe that you can make into a healthy treat with just a couple substitutions and the best part is the kids don't realize they are eating fruits and veggies!

text:
As Rachael Ray would say, "Yumm-O!" I was anxious to eat this right when it came out of the oven, so I ate it warm last night, and it was delicious, but I just finished eating a piece today for breakfast, and it's even better! Like many others, I healthified it: I halved the recipe and used one regular size loaf pan, used 1/2 cup of applesauce instead of the oil, used 1 cup of sugar and 1 egg. I also didn't have baking powder, but I don't think it made a difference (what is the purpose of baking powder anyway?). I also used 1 1/2 cups of frozen blueberries and it is chock full of them -- delicious! Thanks for the recipe, it's a definite keeper and will probably be made for holiday gifts at the office in mini loaf form.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews of this recipe, I also tweaked it up a bit.   It was good....but thought it could be even better.   So I got out my other zucchini bread recipes and tried it again.
I used 3 eggs, 3/4 cup oil with 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce, 2 tsp. vanilla, 1 1/4 cups white sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar, 3 cups zucchini,   2  cups white flour and 3/4 cup whole wheat flour, 1 tsp. salt, 1 tsp. baking powder, 3/4 tsp. baking soda, 2 tsp. cinnamon, 1 1/2-2 cups blueberries and/or aronia berries.   Aronia have less sugar and very high with intoxicants, but only had 1/2 cup at the time.   This time I just combined about 1/2 Tbsp. of white sugar and brown sugar with about 1/4 tsp. cinnamon to sprinkle on the top of the loaves.   Not much variation to my 1st go around but I do really like this and will follow it again next time.   Zucchini bread is rather boring and sometimes dry but with the added 1 cup (I did not squeeze it the 2nd time), cutting back on the flour and the blueberries....so very good!

Turned out amazing! As others suggested, I used 3 cups zucchini, 2 cups sugar, 1/4cup brown sugar, and added nutmeg. I didn’t realize the recipe was for 2 loafs (2 8x4 pans) so I had poured all of it in one deep 8x4 pan...still turned out great! Baked for 1 1/2 hrs on 350F. I loosely covered the pan with foil after 50 min to avoid the top from browning too much. Can’t wait to try it with the whole-wheat modification next time. There will definitely be a next time!

lllll

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe, as written deserves five stars and I have made it in the past following the recipe exactly.  Well, yesterday my neighbor gave me four giant zucchinis so I decided I would make this delicious bread.  Unintentionally what started out as a few minor changes (I wanted to make a healthier version so I substituted apple sauce for the oil and used half white half whole wheat flour) turned into multiple changes to the recipe.  I had a taste for lemon blueberry bread so I added a teaspoon of lemon extract and some lemon zest.  Then, oops, I accidentally put in almond extract instead of vanilla extract.  I did not have fresh blueberries but I had a bag of dried blueberries that I needed to use up so I used those.  I was not sure how the almond lemon cinnamon blueberry combination would turn out but it is delicious.  Thank you for publishing a truly five star recipe - one that is not only excellent as written, but is also forgiving enough to handle a few mistakes.

city:
