region:
None
country:
None
text:
Normally, I make the recipe, as written, the first time and change various items on the second attempt.  However, I will not change anything from this recipe.  Perfect as it is!  My batter yielded enough for two normal-size loaf pans and I had to bake it a little longer due to this reason.  Instead of 50 minutes, I kept it in the oven for an additional 25 minutes.  It still slightly "jiggled" on top, but the edges were brown.  As the loaf cooled, it continued to cook and turned out exceptionally moist!  I used fresh blueberries as I felt that frozen ones would add additional water.

Four stars because I did make a few of changes. I replaced 1/2 of the oil with applesauce and reduced the sugar 1/2 cup and used part white and part brown sugar. text:
Great recipe! 
My minor changes: 

I used two 8" x 4" foil loaf pans instead of the mini pans. These were perfect for the amount of batter and I had no spill-over. I increased the cook time to about 1 hr 15 min.

I used 1 cup of white sugar and 1 cup of brown sugar instead of the 2.25 cups of white sugar.

I also added a tsp of nutmeg.

I would definitely make this again, although I might try to see if I can get away with 3 cups of zucchini next time.

text:
I made a few changes to try to make it a little healthier. First, I only did 1/2 cup of oil along with about half a cup of applesauce. I only  did a total of 1 1/4 cups of sugar (of which 1/2 was brown). Instead of 3 cups of flour, I did two and the third cup was oatmeal (you can put in in the blender if you want it as oat 'flour').  I always add about 1/2 - 2/3 cup of low-fat sour cream to my breads--along with just enough milk to keep the batter from being too thick.  It turned out great.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly. Sprinkled a little cinnamon and sugar on top before baking and then brushed it with butter right after taking out of the oven. It didn’t need it but I liked the light crispy crust it created. I’ve never tasted zucchini bread before but was given a humongous one the other day. This recipe had so many rave reviews I decided this was going to be my first experience. It’s absolutely fabulous! The blueberries sort of melted into the bread as little pockets of sweetness. I filled the mini loaves up to about 1/2” from the top. They rose well and is moist and delicious. Definitely a high five!

region:

country:
None
text:
This is such a great recipe!!! My coworkers are asking if I would bake them for them constantly! I used the recipe as stated, and tweaked a bit and both turned out sublime! My alterations were : Instead of 1c of oil 1/2 cup oil 1/2 cup applesauce, 2 cups white sugar 1/2 cup brown sugar packed, and 2 1/2 - 3 cups, or at least a pound to a pound and a half of shredded zucchini (not drained/ dried) .   Do not dry the zucchini, it adds to the moistness of the bread/muffins.  I made muffins in large tins and cooked them at 350 F for about 23/24 minutes. I also omitted the blueberries and put in 2 cups chopped walnuts and it was fantastic!  Almost like a banana walnut.  Even people who do not like veggies will eat it....if you don't tell them it has zucchini in it!

text:
I like this recipe. I made it as directed.  I liked it so much I bought extra zucchini at the farmers market, shredded it and froze it.  Now, what you need to know about that is there is a LOT of water in zucchini and it separates when it thaws.  I debated whether I should use the water, I did, and it turned out fine.  When I used frozen blueberries the bread turned purple which was a little less appealing but tasted just as good.

text:
As another commenter did, I made these into muffins instead.  Cooked for 18 minutes on 375 and they came out perfectly.  I used whole wheat flour as that was what I had on hand.  I wanted to cut down on the oil and sugar so I used 3/4 cup of vegetable oil and Splenda in place of half the sugar.  Definitely will make again; will follow the recipe to the letter next time to see if the different flour and the additional oil make for even better muffins.

text:
I rely on this recipe as a staple in my home however, I have made numerous additions and alterations. Like I said it's a great staple recipe to work off of if you are inclined to replace and add goodies. 

In the past, I have swapped blues for raspberries, as well as added flax meal, chia seeds. I consistently keep the sugar low and replace the veg oil with coconut oil. Used maple syrup in place of the white stuff and added unsweetened shredded coconut . 

Very versatile and easy to alter on the fly. Keep in mind the more you add, the longer it takes to bake through.

Have fun and be creative!

I hate when comments are like, "I used kumquat instead of blueberries and kale instead of zucchini and it was disgusting!" Of course it was, you changed the whole recipe!

But I did change out the AP flour for Bob's Red Mill 1-to-1 Gluten Free baking mix and it was delicious! I didn't have fresh blueberries available because they're insanely expensive right now, but the frozen ones worked out great. Final change was, in my double batch, I cut 1.5 cups of sugar and subbed unsweetened apple sauce... cuz my kids look cute with teeth :)  I'm making another batch today!

text:
OMG yum. I made this but with other's suggestions: used half coconut oil and half apple sauce (1cup total), used half brown and white sugar (1cup total), used 3 cups of zucchini (water not drained), used half fresh and half frozen blueberries. I only had one 12 hole muffin tin so used that and a loaf tin. Baked muffins for 20mins and loaf for 40mins. So happy with the flavour. Dividing it by 24 serves makes it only 100cals per muffin/slice which definitely fits in my calories (if I can stop at one..) :D stoked!

text:
Really, really good!  I used 1/2 cup veggie oil, 1/2 cup apple sauce, cookie nip, 1/2 white sugar, 1/2 brown, 2 1/2 cups zucchini, 2 1/2 cups frozen blueberries tossed in flower.  I used a sugar mix in bottom of pan, but think I'll  try a crumble on top next time.  My small loaf pan took 1 hour, the larger one took 1 hour 10 minutes.

Display Name:
Cynthia Adams

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5659433.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I  have only ever tried traditional zucchini breads, but decided to try this one today based on its high ratings.  I followed CookieQueen's suggestion of using 3 cups of zucchini, using 2 cups white sugar and 1/4 cup brown sugar, and making a crumb topping made of 2/3 cup flour, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar 1 tsp cinnamon, chopped walnuts and 1 stick softened butter, mixed together by hand and sprinkled all over the top of the loaves before baking.  I used 1 cup chopped walnuts instead of the 1/2 cup in her recommendation.  I also used frozen blueberries because that's what I had on hand.  I used 2 large loaf pans cooked at 350 and it took them about 90 to 95 minutes to bake.  I would start checking them at 1 hr 20 minutes.  It is very good and would be good with some powdered sugar, a thin glaze drizzled over top, or some vanilla ice cream, but I like it just the way it is.

I modified the recipe by using 1.5 cups white sugar, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup olive oil, and 1/2 cup applesauce.  I also used 5 mini loaf pans instead of 4--this makes a lot of batter.  The loaves were beautiful golden brown, very moist, and slipped right out of the pans with just a little bit of butter rubbed on the bottoms and sides before baking.  Will definitely make this again!

text:
I made this per the recipe except I used about half Stevia and half sugar. I debated using lemon zest in place of the cinnamon but decided to stick with cinnamon this time. I baked it in 2 large loaf pans instead of 4 small. I had to bake it for about 65 minutes before it tested done. The batter seemed quite thick to me. I squeezed the zucchini in a towel but gently since I wanted to leave moisture in the zucchini. I am pleased with the results but would like to add a simple glaze to this bread before I serve it.

text:
This is my go to bread for my garden of zucchini! I have made this bread for many friends and family and it always gets rave reviews. I will usually add 1/2 to  1 cup of chopped walnuts to the batter.  I will also, occasionally, add a crumble topping to it, at my husbands request. Other than that, this recipe has all it needs! 
It is a yummy, delicious bread that we love toasted with butter or cream cheese,  the day after it's made!

I made this exactly according to the recipe and it was a big hit at the gathering I brought it to. text:
I made this bread as a compliment to a chicken and root vegetable salad dinner.  I substituted yellow summer squash for zucchini and added one third cup of coarsely chopped walnuts.  I used frozen blueberries coated in flour to keep the bread from turning blue and to suspend the blueberries in the batter.  The finished result was superb.  Both of my guests asked to take home a loaf. We finished one loaf with dinner, sent home a loaf with both guests, and saved one for ourselves. You can be sure I will be making this recipe again very soon.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the BEST sweet bread ever!  I've even made it GF by using oatflour and/or a mix of GF flours.   I usually make enough to share after our annual June blueberry picking trip.  I always get a ton of compliments.  

It seems to have a lot of sugar, so I usually cut back a wee bit.  I've also made "healthier" versions by replacing some or all  of the oil/butter with applesauce, and cut out 1/4 -1/2 cups of the sugar.  Even with these adjustments, the bread is still amazing!    

Be prepared, if making a GF loaf, to have sticky bread.  Oat flour tends to have a stickier and thicker consistency.

Overall, this will always be a keeper for me!  Definitely a favorite!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-02-25T03:05:45.9

It was so good the first time, I made it again and tried a few changes this time -- not that it needed any changes at all, I was just experimenting.  I used two eggs (that's all I had on hand), added 1 cup unsweetened apple sauce, 3 cups white sugar, added an extra 1/4 cup flour, 1/4 tsp each nutmeg and allspice. None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the ingredients exactly, but had to make this in two regular loaf pans because I have no mini loaf pans.

I take issue with these methods employed. For example, I have always put my dry ingredients together and whisked them.  Moreover, I add the undrained zucchini after the wet and dry ingredients are mixed. I have never before heard of checking your bread with a knife! (Ahem, toothpick?)

I made a point of not reading any of the reviews here, before trying this recipe to use up some blueberries we had on hand. Just looking at the reviews now makes me worry it will be too sweet.

Update: I couldn't wait until morning to try this bread, so I take back the statement about it might be too sweet. It is a little on the sweet side, but moist and delicious! Thank you for the recipe!

text:
I made this recipe as written with exception of decreasing the sugar to 2 cups. I did not squeeze out the  excess liquid from zuchinnis after they were shredded because recipe didn't call for it. This did not seem to affect the recipe. I cooked in 2 mini loaf pans and one regular sized loaf pan all together in a toaster oven with convection fan running for 50 minutes. I took the 2 mini loaf pans out leaving the larger pan in for an extra 5 minutes.  The bread is very moist and flavorful. Next time I think I'd like to add more zuchinni  and due to the larger amount, squeeze excess liquid from zuchinni.

The only "problem" I have had is that it seems to stick to the pan. I have to use a spatula and really pry the loaves out. 
Once again though - a very tasty zucchini bread!

text:
My husband is Gluten free so I had to alter this recipe a bit, however he was SO excited.  This was incredibly tasty.  We sliced it and used it as a pancake with eggs and sausage.  Finding anything bread-ie that is gluten free and tasty is very rare.  I substituted my homemade flour (2 cups brown rice flower, 2/3 cups potato starch, 1/3 cup tapioca flour) I used the same amount that the recipe called for, and I reduced the sugar to only 2 cups.  It was great.

text:
I didn't want to make in mini pans. I used my largest bread pan and it was a big bread when done. It took 1 1/2 hours and I thought it would burn going that long, but it did not.  I wish I hadn't had to guess about the timing. We did all like it but I thought it had a tad too much sugar. Next time I will leave out the 1/4 cup, and only use 2, one of which will be brown sugar. I actually feel the batter was a just a bit much for my bread pan.  Next time I may put it in the Bundt pan instead. Yes I would make it again. I am making this again, using the 4 mini loaves as I plan to freeze a few loaves. Also switched to five star instead of four. I still decrease the sugar by 1/4 cup.

After reading lots of reviews, I opted to do half oil and half applesauce, add nutmeg,  seep then increase zucchini to 3 C, coat blueberries in flour to keep from dropping,  and added topping of 2/3 C flour, 1/2 C each brown and white sugar, 1T cinnamon,  2/3 C oatmeal and softened stick of butter.

This is a go to recipe I have used many times.  I always bake it in 2 regular loaf pans.  This time I subbed 1 cup applesauce for the oil. I think it was even better with the applesauce and fat free. Delicious. I decreased the sugar to 3/4 cup of white and 3/4 cup of brown and it was still plenty sweet enough. 
I divvied up the batter between a muffin pan and a bread pan. The muffins came out about 5 minutes before the bread. I preferred their consistency. Loved the recipe!  I made a few very small changes that I think made this recipe perfect for us. text:
This is not only the best zucchini bread I've ever had, it's also the best blueberry bread I've ever had. I loved the strong, but not overpowering, flavors of cinnamon and vanilla. It's also "fluffy," as opposed to dense, like some zucchini breads. As another reviewer suggested, I made 2 large loaf pans, making it in a 350° oven for an hour and 20 minutes. It sounds like a long time, but it is perfect. Try this recipe! You won't regret it!

A cold, rainy day means bake something!  This was the perfect thing. Excellent recipe, but since I must do things differently, I made a few changes. I always go organic, as well here. Delicious! I did not make any changes. My kids couldn't even detect the zucchini! My only suggestion is to avoid a loaf-shaped pan. I split the batter into a quiche pan and a loaf pan. The quiche pan came out perfectly and very uniform. The loaf was uncooked in the middle when the crust was close to being overcooked, so I had to keep cutting out the cooked area and putting the uncooked portion back in the oven.

text:
When I make carrot cake I use half as much oil and replace it with applesauce.  That's what I did with this recipe.  I thought this recipe was too sweet for my taste, so if I make it again I would definitely use less sugar.  This has nothing to do with the applesauce as I use unsweetened.  Also, I think the zucchini should be added last with the blueberries and be folded in for a better final texture.

text:
Delicious! I have made this twice in one week: the first time exactly as recipe states with only white sugar, and the second time I traded one cup of the white with golden brown sugar:  More depth of flavor with the golden brown sugar.

I will also note that I add about eight more minutes of baking time, and all of my loaves come out BEAUTIFULLY perfect,  with glass or dark bake-ware.  Let them sit for at least 10 minutes in pans after taking out of the oven before turning out on a cooling rack. 

EXCELLENT! Even better the next day (if it lasts that long).

text:
I make this every year when zucchinis are plentiful and look forward to it every year, too!  It's a forgiving recipe - I've used more and less sugar, 1/2 whole wheat flour, replaced some of the oil with apple butter/sauce - added nuts, streusel topping, made it in muffins, loaves and bundt pans - it's always delicious and turns out perfectly!  The baking time varies with those versions, of course, but it always does (especially if it's humid).  It is possible to underbake it, though.

region:

country:
None
text:
The blueberries are a great addition to a traditional recipe. Very moist and yummy.  The only changes I made were to use 3 cups of zucchini and substitute part of the white sugar with brown. I also made it in two regular loaf pans, and they had to cook longer, for about an hour. You'll need to check for doneness based on the size of your pan and your oven. In the future, I might cut to 2 cups of sugar. Also, for those who complain that it's dry, you can't squeeze the moisture out of the zucchini! It's essential to keep the bread moist. I will make this again.

text:
This is delicious. Tomorrow will be my 3rd week of making this bread. I make it in 5 mini disposable loaf pans per batch. I usually give 2 away to neighbors or work and we munch on the other loaves the rest of the week. After it's gone, we all get sad. It didn't last 15 minutes in the break room. All neighbors asked for the recipe. The top gets a little crispy, the middle is so moist, it's not too sweet and then you bite into a blueberry, oh and the cinnamon. GAH! Ok, I'll go make it now instead of tomorrow.... 
I only made one change to fit my pantry, 1/2 cup of softened butter and 1/2 cup of coconut oil to substitute the 1 cup of veg oil.

text:
Fabulous recipe. Made a few changes to try to make it a little healthier.  Substituted applesauce for half the oil.  Also used half whole wheat flour half white.  I freeze my grated zuchinni in sandwich bags and then use the plenteous zucchini all winter long.  I also sprinkle a little oatmeal crisp topping on each loaf, but plain oatmeal works too.  My crisp topping recipe is 1 c oatmeal, 1/2 c whole wheat flour, 1/2 c brown sugar and 1 tsp cinnamon.  I just keep a small container in my fridge to use on banana bread and zucchini bread.  Love this stuff.  Thanks for sharing your recipe.

text:
I was looking for something to use some of our blueberries and found this one to use some of the zucchini that was in the freezer.  Defrosted the zucchini and drained nearly a half cup of water off.

Reduced oil to 1/2 c. and used 1/2 c homemade applesauce.  Used 1 3/4 cup white sugar and 2 duck eggs, because I had them and they are great for baking.

Followed the rest of the recipe as written.

Did put a sprinkle of white sugar, brown sugar and cinnamon on top.

Put in 2 loaf pans and baked at 350 degrees F for 65 minutes.

This was really good and very easy. I try hard to find ways to get my boys to eat better. I know there is a decent amount of sugar in here but hey, everything in moderation. My boyfriend and my son both make sour faces when you say zucchini bread. I had to force my boyfriend to even try it. They both loved it. My son (10 yo) asked me to make it again so we are making the second batch in about a month with zucchini he helped me grow in the garden. I add about a 1/4 cup extra zucchini in my attempt to make it as healthy as I can and extra blueberries too. After the first attempt this quickly went down as one of our favorite recipes.

text:
As a novice baker, I was really happy with this zucchini bread. I followed the recipe as printed except for some minor changes. As others have suggested, I subbed in 1/2 cup of applesauce (cinnamon flavored) for half the cooking oil. Because one of my sons loves berries, I mixed in cut up raspberries with the blueberries.  I also inadvertently used 1 tsp of baking soda instead of the called for 1/4 tsp, but the bread still turned out well. Maybe it's a little fluffier but I have nothing to compare it to. I'll have to make another batch to compare.

text:
I can't give this 5 stars only because I tweaked it. 2cups whole wheat pastry flour +1 cup white flour. I followed others suggestions; increased zucchini by 1/2 cup, used 1/2 cup applesauce & 1/2 cup oil, then zest of 1 small lemon, 2 tsp vanilla and 1 tsp blueberry extract, 1/4 tsp nutmeg; used less sugar ( 1 cup white sugar + 3/4 cup brown sugar), added 1/4 cup quick oats, 1/4 cup chopped pecans. Then sprinkled tops with a streusel crumble oat topping with pecans. Made 4 mini loaves & 8 large muffins :) will be freezing a few. Check out my resulting pic.

None
text:
I had lots of blueberries from our produce co-op and decided to try this recipe. I love zucchini bread and was intrigued by the idea of adding blueberries.  I followed tips from other reviewers -- half oil/half applesauce, decreased sugar by 1/4 cup, increased zucchini to 2.5 cups and put the blueberries on flour before folding them into the batter. I got five small loaves. It is tasty, but will not replace the zucchini bread recipe I've tweaked from high school cooking class (39 years ago!) Thanks for the inspiration!

text:
Very Good. I followed other reviewers suggestions and used soft whole wheat flour, added an extra cup of zucchini, used only 2 cups of sugar (actually evaporated cane juice), substituted applesauce for half the oil, added one cup of walnuts and a dash of nutmeg. Makes great mini-muffins also as I had more than four mini-pans and the extra exactly filled a min-muffin pan which baked for about 20 minutes.

This was delicious! I cut the sugar down (1 heaping cup) and I replaced all of the oil with applesauce. I meant to toss the blueberries with some flour to prevent the berries from sinking as another reviewer suggested, but forgot--oh, well--there's always next time. Absolutely amazing! After a friend's garden explosion of zucchini, I needed to find recipes. I tried 4 different breads, this one was hands down the best. text:
So delicious! Pretty simple recipe with excellent results. Liked it just as is. The only thing I might do if serving at a brunch or for guests is add a little streusel topping. This can be made with a mix of flour, brown sugar, unsalted butter, cinnamon and nutmeg. Just did it to step up the presentation. Also, if you don't want to make streusel, you can always reserve thin, circular slices of zucchini to place on the very top to add to the presentation. But really--it's a great recipe as is, too!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe. I lost my stand-by recipe, and thrilled to find this one. It is even better than my old recipe - moist, tender, and loved by the whole family! I plan to take this to an upcoming pot luck dinner. I did not change any ingredients, but I didn't make it as bread. This makes a wonderful cake baked in a 9"x13" greased cake pan and baked for 55 minutes. Test with a tooth pick to be sure the center is done. When it came out of the oven, I dusted the top with powdered sugar. Let cool completely and cover. The next day the powdered sugar will have 'melted' into the cake. Serve with whipped topping if desired (my hubby's favorite way to eat this cake). Although you can serve this the same day it is baked, it is even better the next day. Thanks for sharing this recipe. I'm sure this would make wonderful bread, but we like it as a cake :-).

This was really good!  I used 1/2 cup oil, 1/2 cup applesauce, 1  1/2 cups of white sugar, 1 1/2 cups of white flour, and 1 1/2 cups of whole wheat flour, 2 cups of frozen blueberries (thawed).  I squeezed the excess moisture from the zucchini with paper towels. I used 2 regular loaf pans sprayed well with Pam. It took about an hour with my oven. Lots of compliments!

Loved it! A nice, thick, moist delicious bread. One thing I changed. You don't need SOOOO much SUGAR. You only need a half of a cup. I always cut back on sugar for recipes. I also didn't put salt in it either. I try to cut back on the sugars and salts because why ruin a recipe's healthiness when you can avoid the extra ingredients you don't need? So remember just 1/2 cup of sugar and no salt.

For me it was a little bland and the blueberries didn't pop with flavor as I hoped. I did used a mixer to mix all but the blueberries - so maybe that just melded the flavors together too much. I like that it made 2 (regular size) loaves so I had one for home and one for work - they were both all eaten.

text:
AMAZING!  And I even goofed up the recipe a bit (plus made it vegan with egg replacement instead of eggs)!

First off, I accidentally used squash instead of zucchini - but I think it actually added to the fantastic moisture.  I know, how do you goof that up?  Welcome to my life...

I also didn't have any loaf pans so I just used a 13x9.

Finally, I forgot to put the cinnamon in until after I had already put the batter in the 13x9, so I sprinkled it all over the top and then swirled it into the batter.

Seriously - so amazing!  Hubby and kids (and me) can't get enough!  I will definitely be making this again.  I plan to follow some of the healthier replacements other people suggested.

text:
We just picked a bunch of fresh blueberries and I was looking for a good bread recipe.  Oh, my! This is it.  The only thing I changed was that I substituted half of the white sugar for sucanat.  Even if I didn't do that, this recipe still would have been great.  It's not too heavy and lots of blueberries.  I doubled it right away and I am glad I did.  Instead of putting all the batter in mini pans, I put it into 2 regular loaf pans and  3 mini loaf pans. I baked the regular loaf pans for about and hour and 10 min.

I loved this, my husband loved it, my kids loved it! made some changes to make it healthier and it still turned out fantastic. Substituted all oil with no-sugar added applesauce; used half whole wheat flour, half white; used only egg whites; used one cup Splenda, one cup regular sugar. Also cooked just one large loaf, and it took about an hour and 15 minutes total time. Going to make more once the next zucchini in the garden gets big enough!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made some suggested changes and a few of my own and it came out great! 
First I subbed half wheat flour for the all-purpose flour. Then half applesauce for oil and I used coconut oil for the other half. I upped the baking soda to 2 tsp and the baking powder to 1 tsp(by accident, but it worked out fine). And I used only 2 cups of sugar.
Then because my oldest doesn't like biting into stuff in his bread I pureed the blueberries and drained out a little of the juice. I shredded the zucchini small and pressed out as much of the juice as I could as well. 
This made 6 mini loaves for me. Kitchen tested, kid approved. ;) Thanks for all the suggestions everyone! :)
Next time I am going to try replacing half the sugar with some stevia for a lower carb option.

text:
I made it as is other than I halved the recipe and only had one loaf rather than 2 mini loaves (half the 4).  When halving the recipe, you can only do one egg as it is very hard to get 1 1/2 egg.  I put in 1/2 cup of white whole wheat and one cup of white flour.  That's the only adjustments I made.  It was way too sweet.  There was way too much oil.  I had no problems with it sticking.  It was kind of crumbly and didn't hold together too well when slicing pieces off of it.  My husband loved it though but he loves all things that are very very sweet.  The blueberries were a good addition to the vanilla and the cinnamon.  Next time I will reduce the sugar and substitute some yogurt for the oil.

country:

text:
Wow...these are delicious!  I was looking for a recipe to make to get more goodness in my child who is a picky eater.  These hit the spot! I followed others advice and used 1/2 cup applesauce and 1/2 cup oil.  Used 1 cup brown sugar and 1 and 1/4 cups white.  I also added a pinch of allspice and tossed the blueberries in flour before adding to keep them from sinking to the bottom. I made muffins and the recipe yielded about 23 muffins for me.  I baked at 375 for 25-28 min.  I also chopped my zucchini into almost a puree so it wouldnt be so noticeable to my kid.  Definitely a keeper!

region:

country:
None
text:
This was my first zucchini bread recipe and it was the absolute greatest! My dad usually can't eat banana bread b/c it's so sweet but this didn't hurt his teeth because of the balance between the zucchini and the sugar i did 2 cups of white and 1/4 cup sugar. It was really great. But the reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 was, the recipe says 350 for 50 min. They had it totally wrong, if your going to do it for 350 it needs to be in for 1 hour and 20 min. So if you want it to take less time then that your going to have to raise the heat. 
But over all I will definitely be making it again!

text:
I love to bake and wanted to make something with my blueberries. The only thing I changed in the recipe was substituting half of the white sugar for brown sugar. This was an amazing bread! Everyone I baked it for loved it. No one could tell there was any zucchini in there. Also, if you don't have as much time, make muffins from this recipe (I forgot the time I baked them...16-18 minutes, I think?) They come out as very moist and dense muffins :)

***update: I baked them in a 13x9 glass pan at 350 for 50 minutes, turning the pan around once in the middle. That works too!

text:
I prefer this zucchini bread than any other zucchini bread.  I wouldn't change a thing.  I did have a hard time getting the bread to cook all of the way through but I will keep working at it.  Update: I halved the recipe and here are a few tips.  1) if you can't find zucchini grate 2 italian squash with a box grater, 2) use about a cup and half of shredded italian squash, 3) use 2 eggs, 4) thaw frozen blueberries 5) use 1.5 cups of blueberries and 6) bake in a 9X5 metal loaf pan for 48-50 minutes.  Enjoy warmed with butter...divine!

text:
Yum! I was getting ready to leave for a vacation, and was concerned about some zucchini I had been given going bad while I was gone. I also happened to have blueberries that I also didn't want going bad. Perfect solution! I followed other user's suggestions, and used 1 cup of applesauce instead of the oil, and was happy to increase the fruit content. It was so easy, my 2-year old even had a blast helping by both mixing, and adding the blueberries all by herself (one at a time, but hey, she was happy). I made 2 full-size loaves and baked them for 1 hr. 15 min and they came out perfectly. Nice and moist, slightly dense. I still have one large zucchini left. Debating whether to take it on my trip and make another batch while away.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/247505.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so moist! Followed the recipe almost to the end but could not help my self and made some changes! After shredding the Zucchini I like to put it in a bowl with some salt( about 1 tsp) and let it sit for 15 min. There is allot of water in Zucchini and Salt renders most of the extra water out. You can do that with cucumbers too! Then rinse the shredded zucchini under running water and squeeze the extra water out as much as possible! I take fresh blueberries and freeze it befor adding to the dough, that way they stay whole and don't get mushy when stired with havy dough! I cooked it about 30 minutes longer then suggested in this recipe! Great the next day with cream cheese! Enjoy!

A friend gave me a HUGE zucchini last summer, and I found this recipe for it. I make these as muffins and they never last long in our house. This summer I'm growing my own zucchini, just for this recipe!  The only modification I make is I substitute the vegetable oil with an equal amount of applesauce or extra zucchini. text:
I made some changes, and really liked the results!  Used 1 c. whole wheat flour, 1 c. spelt flour, 1 c. brown rice flour.  Used 1 c. agave nectar instead of 2c. sugar and it was PLENTY sweet!  Also, substituted 1/2 c. applesauce and 1/2 c. sunflower oil, plus 2 "Flax eggs" and only 1 regular egg.  Made it healthy... and still delicious!  Crumble topping was 1/4 c. spelt flour, 1/4 c. evaporated cane juice, 2 T. applesauce, and 1/2 t. cinnamon.  YUM!!!

This was wonderful. I was looking for a recipe to use of some blueberries, and when i came across this I realized I also had 2 zucchini's sitting in the fridge, which is exactly how much you need. I ran out of white sugar so I only used 3/4 white sugar and another 1 1/4 cup brown sugar. Everything else was the same. Not overly sweet, just perfect. I cant wait to try the crumb topping on it as others mentioned next time I make it.

text:
Delicious!  I had to make this twice in two days since my family ate it all up before I even got to try it myself!  I made this exactly as stated using zucchini and blueberries I had stored in the freezer.  I did use two large loaf pans rather than the mini loaf pans and I did substitute 1/2 of the flour with sifted wheat flour for a little health boost.  I didn't have any applesauce on hand but I would like to try to use half applesauce and half oil next time because a cup of oil does seem a little unnessary for the waistline.  ;)  Alltogether a great recipe and I expect many requests for this in the future from my family!  Thank you so much!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is wonderful!!!  My neighbor who hates zucchini bread ate a whole loaf without evening realizing it was zucchini!  I also "healthified" the recipe slightly ... I divided the flour in half and used half all-purpose and half whole wheat flour.  The sugar was split into half brown sugar and half regular sugar.  I also eliminated the oil and used an equal amount of natural applesauce.  Other than substituting healthier ingredients, I followed the recipe totally as-is.  I did set my oven for convection baking, and all four mini-loaves were done in about 40 minutes.  (So you might need to adjust the time if your oven bakes differently.)  As a fun trial, we also kept the recipe as-is and substituted mini-chocolate chips instead of blueberries.  My kids loved both!!!  Enjoy!  :)

Very good!  I changed it up by using...

-1/2 cup "Lighter Bake" (prune puree) instead of oil (fat free but still good)
-1 1/3 cup fructose instead of table sugar (lower glycemic index sugar but not an artificial sweetener)
-1 cup whole wheat flour 2 cups white

Next time I think I'll use raisins instead of blueberries because we LOVE raisins.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it into a coffee cake to take to a potluck.I made 1 1/2 times the posted amount.It made enough for 13x9 glass pan and a little loaf pan.I baked at 325 for about 1 1/4 hour.I made many of the same changes that other posters made~whole wheat pastry flour,1/2 applesauce for oil (used unsweetened,apple-blueberry),brown sugar for white and only 2 1/4 cups in all(plenty sweet for me,even w/out crumb topping),a little more zucchini~3 1/2 c. in all,a little more baking soda(for the extra acidity in brown sugar) and a crumb topping with 3/4 c. each brown sugar and flour and 6 Tb.butter cut in.Several people asked me to write down the recipe for them! It really was excellent!

text:
Good, easy recipe to follow.  I didn't have any blueberries on hand so I added shredded apple to the mix.  I have a habit of making recipe's without reading them through first...so I didn't realize how much batter this was going to make until I was actually mixing it altogether.  I ended up pouring it all into a bundt pan and it came out great.  I also forgot to add the vanilla...and I'm a freak about vanilla but it came out okay.  I don't usually  mess around with recipe's on the first go around but this one is so easy you can do what you want with it and it will still come out great!

I never made zucchini bread before, and didn't know what to expect.  This was great!  I followed the suggestions of others by using more zucchini, substituting half the oil with applesauce, and half the flour with whole wheat flour.  The only change I would make next time is using mini loaf pans rather than a large loaf pan like I did this time.  Thanks for a great recipe!

Yummmmm. I made this for my boyfriend this past summer and used fresh zucchini and blueberries from the local market (I prefer buying from local farmers market whenever possible because it’s better for you and tastes much better) I followed the recipe exactly and it came out perfect. My boyfriend has been begging me to make it ever since (did I mention he ate the whole loaf within the week). I think the blueberries really make this recipe – just make sure the blueberries taste good before deciding to make this recipe because sometimes the blueberries at my local grocery are really lacking in flavor. I will definitely make this again.
